title: Do you feel iPhone is overrated? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m going to try and explain why I think the Iphone is overrated. When I hear the term “It just works” it makes me roll my eyes uncontrollably. Android just works too, and I’m going to give you examples in every category to see which is doing better and faster. Simple task: Enable location IOS: 4 steps go to settingsgo to privacygo to locationtap on location to activateAndroid: 2 steps swipe down to control centertap on location to activateNow consider this real use scenario: Find destination on Google Maps with location disabled: IOSfind destination you’re looking fortap on routeIOS sometimes opens up a popup telling you that you need to enable your location settings with a button that says go to settingsTap on go to Settingsgo to privacygo to locationtap the toggle to enabletap on back to google maps to get back and start navigating.This is NOT good user experience. This is laughable user experience. Androidfind destination you’re looking fortap on routeAndroid popup will tell you that your location is disabled and will ask you if he can activate it for you.Tap Yesstart navigatingStupid decisions made on IOS: If you mute your phone, it doesn’t show anywhere that you’re muted, an icon or something. You have to look at the side of the phone to see if the mute button is activated. Good luck doing that in a dark room.When you get called on IOS, it blocks your whole screen, you just wait there annoyed that you were interrupted while writing your email.The control center is damn right retarded. Somehow the designers from Apple decided that Disable/Enable Rotate your screen is more important than your mobile data or location.If you want to change your brightness you can’t just tap in a spot on that slider like on Android, Nooooo, you have to grab the knob and swipe(that becomes annoying really fast)The Wifi doesn’t show on which wifi he’s connected, you have to go to settings and find out( On Android you see the name of the wifi you’re connected under the wifi icon, and if you tap on it, it shows you other wifi networks) You can’t change your default browser. you have to use safari.Safari has the most annoying scrolling you can find.The notifications on IOS are confusing, ugly, and crowded. If you get 20 notifications from the same app, you’ll have 20 notifications one after another, IOS designers never heard of grouping. John Ive, come on dude.You have a better chance at helping Elon Musk creating his rocket ship than changing your ringtone.You won’t find these stupid decisions on Android. You may think I hate the iphone but that is not the case. I hate people that praise the iphone for what it’s not. I own a Nexus and an iphone 7 plus, they’re both great, but IOS is not better than Android and for damn sure is not more intuitive. It is however a consistent experience which most people find appealing, and I’m fine with that, Android is open and free for everyone to modify it as pleased, that for me resonates more with my beliefs than Apple closed environment. Now, The iphone does do something better than Android, and that is updates. In terms of investing in a flagship phone the iphone is cheaper on the long run. It has a 5 year support, where Nexus/Pixel phones only have 3. Samsung, LG, Motorola, Sony and other manufacturers only offer support for their higher end phones, and only for 2 major OS updates. mostly 2 years. If you took the time to read this, I salute you, and by all means, just use and enjoy your iphone. But please, leave it as it is, amongst the best phones available, not the Messiah of phones.

How many hours a day do you spend on your phone and computer? The average American currently spends 5 hours a day on mobile devices, and 10 hours on screen time altogether. You could break down that 1,825 hours of mobile time by the $1000 price of the iPhone X, and it comes out to 50-cents an hour usage - or you could break it down as a business expense by figuring out how much money it helps you make. The point is, when you spend all day, everyday on these devices, it makes sense to use a high-quality tool, which is what Apple products are. They’re premium devices, so you pay for the name, but in addition to the name you’re paying for outstanding quality & reliability. Are Apple devices overrated? Yes, in terms of branding & marketing - Apple charges a premium for their products and you can find similar competitive products for much less elsewhere. If the quality wasn’t there, then I’d say skip the purchase. However, the quality is there, so the next question to ask is whether it’s worth the money to pay more for something you’re literally going to use all day, everyday. In my opinion its worth it. Ultimately this comes down to the same cost/value proposition that professionals have to make in many fields. Why do mechanics spend more on Snap-On tools? Why do construction companies pay more for heavy-duty Ford or GMC trucks? The answer is simple: these products work better, and they last longer. It’s not worth the extra money for a gizmo that you’ll use once and month and forget, but when you look at the time investment people put into phones & computers, then it makes a lot more sense.

Not at all. From personal usage perspective, I have ‘3 S’ criteria when choosing a smartphone platform SecurityStabilitySimplicityOf course there are other criteria like the hardware specs, but iOS performs well in all these 3 core areas and also in overall usability. And unlike Android OS where you need to regularly kill apps in the background, you do not need to do that in iOS because the app states are saved and thus consumes minimum resources. Thus my 7 years of using iPhones I have never encountered persistent crashes. I don’t need the coolest features, just a tool that helps me stay productive and enable me to do what I need to do easily. Is the iPhone overrated for me? No. Something lesser known, Apple puts a lot of effort to make the iPhone usable for the disabled. Why the iPhone 5s is a terrific accessibility tool Apple’s new ‘Designed for’ videos highlight Accessibility features with personal stories Apple worked with hearing-aid firms on direct connection to iPhones, with free licensing Is the iPhone overrated when it made a world of difference to users with special needs? From enterprise perspective, I’m also one of the IT guys in a large multinational company. Security is the most important factor for us when choosing a mobile device platform. If you read the iOS security guide, the first sentence says it all - “Apple designed the iOS platform with security at its core.” https://www.apple.com/business/docs/iOS_Security_Guide.pdf iPhones and iPads are secure yet easy to deploy, easy to support, and when you need help from Apple, they provide excellent support. I doubt we can get the same level of experience from any Android smartphone. Is the iPhone overrated when 98% of Fortune 500 companies are testing or deploying it? With most major companies already using iOS, Piper Jaffray doesn't see IBM deal surging Apple sales Is the iPhone overrated when the value you get from the iPhone exceeds the price you pay? Moreover all my iPhones are bought second hand.

Yes they are over-rated. For the stuff which they offer, if taken seriously, there are lot of other players that provide similar or you can say 90% of the features and specs at almost half of their prices. But whatever it be, Apple products are tend to be sold. They have such a goodwill & brand reputation that enables them to charge higher for their product. But Apple is a brand that invests a very big chunk of its profits and reserves into R&D (Research & Development). If you notice their phones of each generation, you’ll see a better technology & a better user interface. This is because they innovate something or the other in each and every iPhone they launch. Moreover, as per my experience, Apple is the best brand when it comes to After Sales Services. After Sales Services take a big lot of money for a company because it is neccesary to have the best after sales service possible as consumer if satisfied probably will be loyal to your brand. So it all depends on you that which type of consumer you are. If you are a consumer who’s priority is luxury and premium stuff, iPhone is never a overrated phone but if you are a consumer who’s priority is the best value for your money, iPhone would not be considered by you. In general speaking, yes Apple products especially iPhones are over-rated.

I thought iPhone was overrated few years ago. I used to own few generations of iPod touch which was one fourth the price of an iPhone. At the same time I had high end android phones mainly because of the bigger screens which was very helpful for media consumption. Somehow while handling both the devices over the years, iOS seemed more reliable to me. I realised that I was using the smaller screen iOS device more than the bigger flagship android phones. In those days I always tried to make my android device behave more like iOS .. for example Greenify to shut down useless background running apps. Juice defender to reclaim RAM, rooted just to get the latest android OS etc.. in the end I gave up and took the plunge for the iPhone Plus when it was launched. Yes I paid a high price. But believe me.. I never felt I was cheated and I keep on upgrading just because I can always sell off my previous iPhones at quite good a price which was never the way on my android days. Android gives anybody lots of freedom. Users tend to misuse the freedom by using pirated apps, freeloading lots of media files(which are scanned by the os frequently) etc. Also the problem is that freedom is not one way.. Developers run freely with their nasty codes in the background too. And also this freedom comes at a cost, Google keeps a tab on everything you do, everywhere you go and even everything you want to do updated neatly in their servers. Google likes to make money continuously of its users, I am not saying it wrong, it's just their business model, otherwise how are they supposed to make money for R&D and development. Apple likes to take the money all upfront, with the device. Also in recent times Apple has been known to protect its users data from higher powerful organisations. These has made me and I believe most other Apple fanboys rate iphone so high. iPhones are not overrated, but rather I believe its perfectly placed at the TOP.

I bought my first iPhone recently. The SE 2020 edition. I like it so far, especially compared to my previous phone, the Motorola G7 Optimo Maxx. I don’t think it’s fair to compare these two because one is a $200 brand new and the other was $550 (I got the 256gb version). But I will try to be fair. I don’t think my particular phone is overrated. The advantage of iPhones over their competitors, the BIG advantage, is software support. Not just apps, but security. Apple actually supports their devices, and will continue to push updates, especially security updates, 5 years after launch. Which means that I can keep this phone for 5 years without resorting to rooting it and installing LineageOS or something crazy like that. Sure it lacks some of the features of more expensive phones, and even lacks a few that my Motorola has at half the price (bigger screen, headphone jack, expandable storage, and face unlock), but apps behave like they should (my Motorola, with it’s slower processor, launches them slower, and I get some glitches and random crashes on a few), things load quicker, and shopping for 3rd party accessories is easy. The iPhone 10 and above, which costs around $1000 I think would be overrated, because I think that spending a $1000 on something better be making you money or be directly linked to an activity making you money (like buying a car to drive to work), especially at my income level. But I break that rule once or twice myself, having spent $1000 on building my own rifle (in my defense at least $200 was replacing parts I broke because I’m an idiot and it was my first time), so I can’t judge too hard.

I used to. I used to think the iPhone was overrated, overpriced, restrictive and generally dead average. Then my dad took the plunge and got an iPhone 6. Despite my own reservations about his decision, I found myself drawn to it, the design, the way it worked, it was just appealing to me. I waited patiently for my contract to run down and got myself an iPhone 7 on launch day. I admit freely that I was wrong. It may sound like a bit of a cliché, but it's difficult to describe what owning an iPhone feels like to someone who hasn't ever experienced it. Other people often ask me “"What can it do that my phone can't?” It isn't about that, though. It's about the level of the performance that the iPhone is able to deliver consistently and the way in which it combines power, simplicity and a fantastic overall ecosystem together in an appealing design. The iPhone is NOT overrated. Nor is it overpriced. Sure, they are expensive, but by definition, something can only be OVERpriced if the market as a whole decides so. Based on the iPhone’s sales figures, there is a sizeable portion of people who are happy to pay the price demanded by Apple in exchange for the product. TL/DR: NO. I've enjoyed every day of my iPhone and I look forward to enjoying many more.

APPLE. The name sounds so convincing.  The only brand thats maintaining its reputation for a long time. While you see apple as an over-hyped product, Apple is quite a beneficial one. There are many reasons why apple products are much costlier in india than in U.S or other countries. Lets us see some of the reasons why Apple never falls down. CAMERAS:-No doubt, the Apple cameras are one of the finest cameras that you will ever see in the smartphone category. The triple lens rear camera can shoot videos at 4k 60fps resolution, capture ultrawide shots. It has great capability of capturing photos in impressive low light conditions, both in front and rear cameras. Many other competitors like samsung, Oppo, Vivo, Oneplus have better cameras than them but apple outsmarts them in terms of engineering. It could shoot videos underwater.Apple offers a great variety of options such as Time-lapse, Slow motion, a varriety of potrait options, great clarity.The in-built iMovie can edit videos and photos in a great quality. It can crop photos, add filters and many more. 2. DISPLAY:- The Apple iPhone posses a liquid retina display on models like iPhone XR and other new models. A Liquid Retina Display is a type of LCD display, currently only found in the iPhone XR and iPad Pro .  Like the regular Retina display found in other iPhones, the Liquid Retina Display relies on a higher level of pixels-per-inch to create a paper-like screen effect where pixels are not visible to the naked eye.However, unlike the Super HD Retina Display found in the iPhone X, iPhone XS and iPhone XS Max, the Liquid Retina Display in the iPhone XR and iPad Pro rely on an miniaturised LCD display panel rather than an OLED one.The liquid retina display has a resolution of 1792 x 828 and a pixel density of 328 ppi( pixel per inch). 3. SECURITY:- The iPhone has one of the toughest security in the world.Data security. iCloud secures your information by encrypting it when it's in transit, storing it in iCloud in an encrypted format, and using secure tokens for authentication. For certain sensitive information, Apple uses end-to-end encryption. The apple products are the toughest ones to crack. Apple products almost clears each and every bugs in it as soon as a developer user reports it to apple.The fingerprint scanner could tell if a person is really alive or dead. If the person is dead, then the phone will not unlock.The face id is more secure in apple iphones.The face id uses TrueDepth camera. It is activated by tapping the screenApple face id use 30,000 infrared dots that maps the contours of the face, relatively remembers the location once you activate the face id. 4. PACKAGING:- Apple tests and uses packaging over 1,00,000 times to see which of the packaging is bset suitable for the customers. Apple makes its package more artistic and visually appealing. Every corner of the box is clean and the plastic covers are attached by static so peeling off gives immense pleasure. The packaging is minimalistic white.  The packaging on an Apple watch is quite satisfying. Once you tear the plastic thincoat on the box, you feel a velvet like touch that is pleasing to the customer. Inside the package, you find the Apple watch strap. The feeling of pulling the strap is on cloud 9.The way how iPads are packed is extraordinary. You got to peel the plastic sheet thats covering the device. Thats satisfying to the core. 5. CUSTOM OS:- Android is the most used os in the world. It is used from a middle budget phone such as mi 5a to one plus 8, android covers everything. But iOS only has Apple covered.  Since android is covering 75 percent of phones, it needs a common os that would suit all of the phonesFor example, if android is having os for high resolution cameras, then low resolution phones cannot use this feature. So some features must be compromised.So Apple has its own os which could used in boosting the efficiency of RAM mldule and many others.6. POWERFUL PRODUCTS:- Apple released some of the greatest products in the industry such as the iPad pro 2020, iPhone XR, iPhone 11 series, and many others. These versatile products could be suitable to anyone who uses it, although mac os is a little bit harder to use. Many Professionals use macbook for coding purposes as macOS is more powerful. Many softwares could be used in macOS.7. APPLE ECOSYSTEM:- The Apple ecosystem is the best of its kind. The Apple ecosystem is a beautiful, welll crafted garden for Apple users.  Imagine a scenario that:- You are a person working for a very reputable software company, at a salary of 150K INR per month. At the same time, you are a entertainment freak.You get Apple watch, iPhone 11 pro max, Apple pencil, Macbook air, iPad pro 2020 and Airpods pro from your hard earned money. You connect all of them to your iCloud. After setting up your security such as fingerprint and face id in the devices. You now connect your airpods to all your iPhone. So you are working in your Apple desktop at home. You are preparing for an important meeting. You finished the documents required for your meeting. So you are leaving to the office with your macbook pro and other devices( except the desktop :).Oops. You forgot to take hard copy of your documents? No problem. Apple gets you covered there. Your iCloud syncs your documents and you can continue from where you left. Impressing, isn’t it? So you are feeling the urge to hear music. So you take your AirPods out. Once you flip them, they automatically sync with your iCloud. So there is no need of connecting it. Impressive, isn’t it? The airpods stops music once they get removed out of the ears so you can start from where you left off.So you go to the office, show your presentation stored on iCloud and sucessfully present it. After comming back home, you watch netflix on Apple tv, comfy on cushion. This is apple’s ecosystem. It gets you connected, where ever you go, and whenever you go. P.S: My 4th answer ~By Greg Heffley

Why would I? You already stated as an objective fact that “iPhones are overrated,” and then set up a challenge to change your mind. That sounds like a game, and one I’m not interested in playing. Of course, when people say something is “overrated,” what that actually means is that it’s overrated for them. It’s an opinion based on what they know about something against what they perceive to be valuable. And it sounds like iPhones are overrated for you. I have no reason not to believe you. Why should I spend time to try to convince you otherwise? And I have no idea how I’d convince you anyway, since you haven’t given any hints about why you believe iPhones are overrated. You might be the kind of person who only wants the latest Samsung or Google Pixel phones. Or perhaps you felt that Windows Phone or even the Palm Pre represented the apex of smartphones, and it’s all been downhill from there. Or maybe you’re the kind of person who also thinks flip phones are overrated and that rotary landlines are where it’s at. Or perhaps you’re actually a closet iPhone fan, and you’re trying to crowdsource reasons or excuses to get a new iPhone. I have no idea. Regardless, it does seem to me that not everyone who enjoys arguing about phones carries an iPhone.

I definitely have mixed views on this. When the iPhone was released, it was undeniably one of the best phones released till date. And it seemed to have that consistent performance. It gave new features and more things to look to. Then slowly, it didn’t exactly give a new feature, which will catch on in the future (personally I feel with touch id was last one). Apple focused more on giving a lag free device and interface. Apple has concentrated more on giving its target audience the product they want. iPhones have low RAM compared to Android devices in its same category, but even with the low RAM it does perform nearly as well as the other devices. The camera is undeniably amazing too. When android popped up giving more features than the iPhone, people switched to Android. People wanted new features more and more, unfortunately Apple hasn’t focused on that a lot. Price is a problem for many phones, for phones manufactured by Apple, Samsung, LG, do have high price phones, but this is because of the money spent on advertising and perception of the product. Take Oneplus One for example, it didn’t have high costing advertisements and a not so famous brand image, therefore a low price on the phone. I feel that the high-tech companies could reduce the price overall, especially a $100 increase for an extra 32Gb? Think that’s a bit too much. When talking about the features about the phone, it’s subjective to personal views. If you feel that a device needs top-notch new features of next year, then Apple would seem to be overrated. If you feel that a device needs top-notch performance, which can be found in a phone of next year, then Apple wouldn’t seem overrated. Personally, I feel that phones since 2016 have near perfect performance, and I wouldn’t pay extra money to have that increment of performance, because the one I have now seems good for me. So I would go for a phone with similar performance but with more features. I feel that certain features make the iPhone overrated, but at times its also just a great phone.

As an android phone user, I do think that iPhones are overrated. Here is why I think that: 1)Lack of good display: In a time when most if the brands are giving high quality OLED displays and HD resolution, Apple devices mostly have a 720p displays and the screen doesn't get very bright outdoors. 2)Battery capacity: The problem with iPhone is the battery, especially if you have the iPhone 6/7 series phones. The capacity would not be enough for people to last a whole day without having to charge it. On top it that, they provide a 5W charger for dinner phones or 18W if they are generous. Whereas, most androids today, have big batteries and a fast charger to fill up the juice real quick. 3)Creating a problem, selling the solution: Apple was the first company to remove the 3.5mm headphone jack, only so that they could charger their loyal followers more money to buy a player of airpods. There are also rumours that Apple won't be giving a charger with the iPhone 12, so there's that. Design improvements: Apple had stuck to a design right from the iPhone 1 to iPhone 8, having a small phone and thick bezels. Now, they have gone to a big notch on top since the iPhone X. Apple fanboys, please don't get hurt by this post. I don't mean to hurt your sentiments. :)

Sorry for the long winded answer. Honestly the differences are small these days and it really is starting to come down to which one you like more. Do I personally think it's overrated? Yes, yes I do i dislike the iPhone and find that for what it offers vs cost is crazy just like some of the Android powered phones only more so with the iPhone. I find it funny with this talk of lasting awhile and being stable for years etc, however most iPhone users are upgrading every two years. Basically every new model for a large portion of them. In that time neither phone with either operating system is going to be so obsolete as long as your comparing equal devices. I see far far too many comparing the iPhone to cheap entry level smartphones powered by Android and declare the iPhone and ios to be vastly superior. As if it's a surprise the thousands dollar phone is superior to the 50 - 100 dollar one. But you can look at this as my opinion, really. I prefer the ability to do what I want how I want it without apple telling me if it's ok or not or paying a fortune and still not getting those things. Oh and iTunes…….just yea probably another big part of my dislike. But on the other side if you like the locked system, because you feel it provides you with a better experience and especially if your already heavily invested in the apple ecosystem then it's really up to you too decide if it's overrated, overpriced, or whatever have you. As I said my answer is yes after using both I have come to that answer. A bit of bias, I'm sure? However imo it's the same for those who think the opposite of me since as I said both sides high-end phones are good. Calling either junk as if they don't do what they were made to both do and extremely well at that, is just blind fanboys. Now of course if it's junk to you because you personally don't like it that's valid imo. So yea overrated? For me? Of course. For you? That's for you and your wallet to decide.

No. When buying a smartphone, many people only observe numbers, for example: how many GB ram there is, the processor, the megapixels of the camera… The iPhone may seem overrated while comparing these criteria, since, overall, the iPhone technical detail are slightly inferior compared to other high-end phones. For example, while Galaxy S8 has 4 gb of ram, iPhone 8 has 3 gb. But people forget that the iPhone has something almost no other phone has: 100% software-hardware compatibility. This integration allows the iPhone to make more with less, making it last longer than other phones. Two friends of mine, for example, changed from their Galaxy S7 to a iPhone 6 and 7, respectively, and are much more satisfied, considering they went from newer phones to older ones. Concluding, the iPhone has one special thing, in my opinion, that makes them a non-overrated phone: durability. While many android users see their phones laggy and slow after no more that 2 years of usage, iPhone users can enjoy their phones (and software updates) for 3 years - or maybe even more, depending on the user. This makes the investment of paying more in a iPhone worth the cost. (sorry for my English since I'm not a Native English speaker)

Some aspects are and some aren't. For example until the iPhone X it had a repetitive design. The iPhone 7 and 7 plus was released aroud the same time as the Xiaomi Mi Mix and had a less premium build and design in comparison. It also felt less unique due to it's design as it looked very similar to a iphone 6. It's performance was top notch at the time and the sme held true for it's camera, ear piece and speakers. The 7 plus had a very good IPS panel that had a good PPI (thus a nice sharp screen) and good color reproduction whereas the iphone 7 only had good color reproduction but not a good PPI that led to the screen appearing a bit jagged. The iPhone 7 had a average battery but the 7 plus had a good battery. The camera is better on the 7 plus and most of these points hold true for the iPhone 6, 6s and 8 series. However compared to the MI Mix, iPhone 7 series fell short on several key areas. It had a less luxiourious (subjectively) feel, less impressive design, less standout features (in screen ear piece and proximity sensor, ceramic build, etc.), less battery life, less screen real state despite iPhone 7 plus being almost the same size (slightly smaller), less storage on the base model, etc. The iphones didi have more performance, better camera and ran ios along with a few other factors. With the release of the iPhone X apple rectified some of the issues but with a massive price tag of $1000 which is the same price as a Gtx 1060 gaming laptop. The iPhones Xs series increased the price even more and were basically the same as a iPhone X. The iPhone Xr is at a lower price but offers a worse screen, no quick charge, slightly less premium build for a higher price than the competition. The phone’s display isn't bad nor is it’s build quality, but for it's asking price of $750 dollars it shpuld offer a screen that's on par with the competition. For example the Sony Xperia XZ2 compact offers a smaller 5′ 1080p LCD screen for about $500–600 that is sharper than apple's screen. So the iPhones are overrated because of the features they provide at their respective price points when compared to the competition.

Recently All of my phones were Androids except the one i got the couple of years back. I got an iPhone considering Android has some limited features and everyone was creating all this hype about iPhone.  The best i can be say is that there's little to no difference. Why should i pay twice as much for an iPhone for half the space of an Android as i did? I went back to Android. . . . Same price for 2x the space. Some of the commenters are talking about all the things iPhone did that Android doesn't. Ok but i think when these comments were made because my current Android does all the things i did on that iPhone and much more easily. Going back to Android is like old home week(although I'm using iphone too) . IPhone also does not last longer than any of my Androids did. . . None more than 3 years and the battery started becoming shit pretty early on. I felt like i had to keep it in charging constantly. This is pretty much how I've felt about the iPhones and it's too much overrated.

So lets look at things you cannot do/get on an iPhone- Install apps from outside the Appstore.Make any customizationsTransfer files from your computer to an iPhone.Multi-tasking.Expand storage.The latest specs.( Screen resolution , features etc. )Value for money accessoriesReplace your batteryMake siri understand you all the timeBut people will still buy it saying “Bhai iPhone hai , sabse badiya”( Bro its an iPhone , always the best ) LOL. Do you think that the iPhone fanboys care that much of the features in their iPhones is ancient? Nah…. beacuse it is a STATUS SYMBOL. So yes , it is definitely overated. (No, i am not poor. These points have been put up by a former iPhone user who switched to android and is most likely not switching back.) Peace out ☮️

Not really because iPhone is a ‘silent killer’. I own iPhone 7 with 128 gb storage. It took lot of struggle for me to switch from android apps to iPhone apps and other functionalities. For instance the notification bars for Facebook in android are located at the top, unlike in iOS - located at the bottom. Same applies to whatsapp and many other applications. Pros - Look and feel - No doubt everyone loves the UI of the iOS more. Performance -It’s highly unlikely that your iPhone will hang. The iOS is designed in a such way that the phone performance remains constant even when you are running several apps at single time. The security of the iOS is the best compared with Android and Windows. iPhone users enjoy the priority while the applications updates are pushed to app store. Cons - Missing Bluetooth, With iPhone 7 you can’t charge phone and listen music at the same time,Battery life sucks. So, as long as you are comfortable with those limitations, iPhone is not overrated.

It’s a both yes and no from my experience. In a typical human psychology, people would tend to justify with various reasons (valid or not) the amount of money they have spent on products that’s way affordable for the person. When it comes to iPhone, that’s a classic example of that. Also correlated to psychology would be the sense of belonging and status symbol that carrying the latest and greatest iPhone would bring to the user, at least for the impression they thought they would get. That wouldn’t work if one were to carry a phone that’s more than 3years old. I’ve personally used an iPhone and gave up due to much of the simpler needs I could do on the equivalent in Android. Like what the previous post have mentioned about location toggle, to check on which wifi you’ve connected , notifications, and so forth. The plus point in an iPhone would be the support of longer than any Android phones. Guaranteed updates for more than 3 years, but i doubt any fans would hold on to the phone for more than 3years. Another plus point would be its integration with Mac. Receiving calls and messages are way easier and you could just interact with it without touching your phone. Apart from the points above, I really couldnt thought of any advantages for paying that price for an iPhone. But is that overrated? The answer depends on how open minded you are.

Not at all !!! You never know unless you use it. I was an Android user for long time. I bought 2nd hand iPhone from a shop where i sent my Android for repair. After that i am in love with it. The touch is exceptionally smooth.Combination of hardware and software is so compatible, that it never hangs.Apple team indeed have focused a lot of attention to each and every single details while designing it, That you use it for a day and you will be in love with it.After using it, I bought another iPhone 7 and now i have iPhone 7 and an iPhone 6s Plus. Trust me, Use it then you will say its worth spending money for it.

Overrated , no unless you listen only to those people who use android and like to bash the iPhone because it doesn't have the latest bell and whistle . It is priced below what some android phones are at and in line with what others are charging when the phones are of equal build and processing power . Its a different animal than a galaxy phone . To compare it to a s8 is like comparing a Lotus Elise to a Ferrari f40 and then complain thats its not as good because it can't do near 200 mph . Its a great and reliable phone that will be supported for on average for 5 years , can't say that from an android ( and no rooting and side loading a hacked version doesn't count because you can do that with iOS also if you wanted to ). Why do you want to waste money every year or so on a phone thats expensive for one and two be outdated or have limited support after the sale and lets not talk about the after sale service . I haven't seen any Motorola , LG , Huawei , or Samsung stores were if I have a problem with the phone I can take it in and get it fixed or replaced in a decent amount of time . For what your paying for an iPhone I would call it a very good investment .

Maybe iPhone is overrated. There is nothing in iPhone 7 that is better than a Samsung 7 Edge. Lets compare with S7 Edge as S8 is too much for Apple to Handle. Looks - Samsung 7 Edge beats iPhone 7 Hands down Price - S7 Edge is far better value for money. Display - You try 7 Edge once and you will be hooked on to it. The best display in the world next only to maybe S8. OS - The Android OS itself is awesome and works great with Samsung Add ons. Ease of Use - I am sure not Fanboy would say Apple is the easiest phone to use. Remember we are comparing iPhone 7 to Edge 7 and not the latest 8 series. So when it comes to all the above i would say and every Samsung Edge user would agree iPhone is no match to the S7 Edge. I also will say The Edge is a far greater phone that any iPhone ever built. So by now Samsung should have made Apple run for cover. But… There is this One More Thing !!!!!!!! The peace of mind you have when you use an Apple product, be it iPhone or iPad or iMac or the MBA. Its priceless. Its because you know damn sure this damn ****ing Apple thing just works. So this simple iPhone thing JUST WORKS. And hell yeah it is overrated. Note : I am not a Apple Fan Boy. Yuck!!! I hate to agree. But this thing still works.

Thanks for A2A. No. iPhone has many things which only you can understand once you use it PROPERLY! iPhone will give you updates of latest released phones to coming 5–6 years and it's more than enough. You can use up-to-date software for 5 years.After sales, if your phone is in warranty and your phone got some major issue then they'll replace it.You can do almost everything using Siri without navigating your phone.Still, it's hard to compete with iPhone 5S and this phone released back in September, 2013.So, spending 60k on a phone which can be used for 4–5 years and almost no phone can compete to it even phones which are released years after then it's not over-rated.  Hope this helps!

Not at all. I used an android phone for years because that’s what my company gave me. My wife had an iphone. I had to reboot the android phone weekly at least. Apps were not as nice and polished on android as they are on the iPhone. etc. I finally got an iPhone after the 6S came out. What a difference. It’s not at all about speeds and feeds. Processor speed and memory (not storage space) are not what makes a phone. It’s the daily usage. I hardly ever have to restart my iPhone. It works! It’s that simple, it just works. It works with the car audio system, it works with blue tooth speakers, it works with my bluetooth headphone, it just works. Who gives a hoot about MHz of processors in phones? That doesn't matter!

No, not at all. If you're familiar with Gestalt psychology, one of its concepts is that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. The iPhone and the Apple ecosystem work that way. The value just multiplies as you use it and get deeper into it. I live in a country where buying an iPhone straight up with cash can mean having to save up for 12 months for 80% of the population. But I don't regret spending money on this device, nor my other Apple products.

I’ve been using an iPhone since the first one that came out in 2007. I had regularly upgraded my phone every two years until iPhone 6. This year, as I did not find anything new in particular with the iPhone in the subsequent releases, iPhone 6s and 7, I contemplated a lot and bought into a Samsung Galaxy S8. Within a week, I understood WHY Apple products are so premier. I’m not saying the S8 was any less premier, but when you compare the ecosystem of the phones, the way the OS interacts with the hardware and other installed apps, iPhone scores way way way above any other phone. The S8 being such a beautiful phone and at the best quality, it still didn’t give the performance and smoothness I used to get from my iPhone 6. I would easily and surely conclude iPhone is not at all over-rated. You get the best performance and stability for the price you pay.

Yes and no. I won’t argue that they are well designed devices, and Apple knows exactly how to cater to the “I just want it to work” market. And in that regard they do live up to what they promise. Except when something does go wrong, they are actual nightmares to fix without factory resetting just because they are so locked down, but that’s besides the point. But that madness of crowds pushing and shoving to get one on launch day? Nah, its just a phone, not Jesus arriving annually.

I used to think that it was overrated until I used but now it's little more complicated than that. If you take an iPhone see the specs on the paper it won't make any sense but once you start using it it's a different ball game. It works like a charm even after 2–3 years and you will get software update on day one no matter what country you are in. In that ways it's not overrated But, it's always not make sense like for example the screens on iPhone are as good as 200$ phone and we don't know when we will have screen quality like Samsung (they are best I have seen) and they do things that most 200$ phone can do in day to day life. So in that ways it's way too overrated. But if you are in Apple ecosystem nothing makes more sense than iPhone or any Apple products because there's not a single ecosystem that works so seamlessly like Apples does and they are most secure next to blackberry.

Thanks for the A2A. No, Apple is not overrated. In fact, most of the time (especially recently) they are underrated. People keep buying Apple products because they have the best user experience, the best ecosystem, and the best customer support. They also have better resale value than any competing products, last longer, and require less support — which means people who use Apple products are generally more productive than those who don’t. The cost of ownership of an Apple product is actually less than any of the competing products. This has been shown over and over and over again. It is one of the main reasons Apple products are actually underrated.

No, but it is hardly perfect. It is very expensive, inflexible, and I am not crazy about Apple apps in general (iTunes, I am looking at you!). However, the user experience is generally very smooth, simple, consistent, and straightforward, and the system is relatively secure and reliable. That’s why people like it! I have used and written apps for both Android and Apple, and while I definitely miss the flexibility and freedom one has with Android, I have come to appreciate what a nice system the iPhone is. Especially for the mass market.

Overrated isn’t the correct word, overpriced is. I’m an active android and iPhone user. I’m using both as my daily driver (but lately I tend to use the iPhone more). Both iOS and android are a great OS with different pros and cons. iPhone is a great smartphone supported with a great OS. The advantage of iPhone when compared to Android smartphone is Apple build the hardware and software altogether. The result is a stable smartphone, with smooth and fast performance. So I rate this phone s highly, till when we talk about the price.

I don’t think that apple products are considered as overrated: apple can manage both its hardware and software together to make products that are considered, (even from android fans) very good products. Maybe some of the Apple events were overhyped in the past few years, but things have changed since then.

Yes they are over priced and so over rated…. It depends on your need ! If you need a specs packed phone (108mp camera, 12gb ram, in display fingerprint, amoled display etc etc) then iphone is overpriced for you. If you want a sweet , simple , long lasting, good looking and security packed phone where security and longevity is main priority then android is overpriced. An iphone 11 pro max is less than oneplus 8 pro (others) in case of specs. But an iphone SE is much better than oneplus 8 pro (others) in case of security.

Not for me. It’s expensive, sure, but it’s beautifully built, has the most stable OS, with definitely the best App store experience. I replace mine every 2–3 years so the cost isn’t that high when you compare it to the depreciation of any other high end piece of technology.
No. The apple eco system is in a class of its own. If you prefer high quality stuff, then its apple. If thats not your thing, then maybe the iphone will look over rated.

If the question is about iphone in general i would say no they arent overrated. Because they are sheep that just get them because they are popular despite Android phones largely being cheaper and better, often having features on their phones years before Apple.

One thing to consider is that the iPhones are nearly unhackable. Android phones are easily hacked for a price. If there is zero potential for you ever being hacked, whether it be by a loved one or employer, to me either is a good choice.
